fields.text: Bernie Sanders has stormed through Madison Wisconsin this past week bringing a record number of people to his speech. While in Colorado he was able to bring in just over 5000 people to watch him speak, but in Madison, WI, he was able to pull in just over 10,000 people almost doubling his previous record set for this upcoming election. Looks like he is on the right track.
fields.title: Bernie Brings Biggest Crowd of This Campaign

fields.text:
Hillary Clinton’s campaign is “worried” about Bernie Sanders, whom a top Clinton aide described as a “serious force” in the 2016 battle.

“We are worried about him, sure. He will be a serious force for the campaign, and I don’t think that will diminish,” Clinton Communications Director Jennifer Palmieri said Monday in an interview with MSNBC's "Morning Joe."

“It's to be expected that Sanders would do well in a Democratic primary, and he’s going to do well in Iowa in the Democratic caucus.”
Sanders, an independent senator from Vermont, has emerged as Clinton's main foil in the Democratic primary.

While he's still more than 40 percentage points behind Clinton in virtually all national polls, he's greatly improved his stock in the early primary states. 

A new Quinnipiac University poll released last week found he doubled his share of Democratic supporters in Iowa in just seven weeks. Some polls in New Hampshire show Sanders less than 10 points behind Clinton.

Palmieri said Sanders's rise won't prompt a shift toward negative campaigning and that Sanders's strong crowds only underscore the differences in the campaigning tactics between the two campaigns. 

“We don’t need to attack each other. He'll run his campaign, we'll run ours. The imperatives for us are different. We think what works for her, particularly in Iowa, is doing a lot of small events, staying a long time, being one of the last people, if not the last person, to leave the room. That works better for us right now,” she said.

“It's going to be a slog, but I feel like she will win.”

-http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/246910-team-clinton-worried-about-sanders
fields.title: Team Clinton 'worried' About Sanders

fields.text:
WASHINGTON -- Frustrated with the historic number of voters who chose not to participate in this year's midterm elections, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) on Friday announced his intention to introduce legislation that would make Election Day a national holiday to give Americans more opportunity to vote.

"In America, we should be celebrating our democracy and doing everything possible to make it easier for people to participate in the political process. Election Day should be a national holiday so that everyone has the time and opportunity to vote. While this would not be a cure-all, it would indicate a national commitment to create a more vibrant democracy," the progressive senator said in a statement.

Turnout in Tuesday's elections clocked in at a paltry 37 percent, compared to about 41 percent in 2010, according to data from the United States Elections Project. If that projection holds, it would be the lowest voter turnout since 1942.

The voters who did show up to vote largely skewed older, whiter and more male compared with other election cycles, and the results were obvious. Republicans picked up control of the Senate, gained seats in the House, won key gubernatorial posts and greatly expanded their hold on state legislatures. Younger and minority voters, on the other hand, largely stayed at home. Voters in the 18-29 age range made up only 13 percent of the electorate, compared with nearly a quarter that were seniors, who tend to support Republicans.

President Barack Obama acknowledged the matter in a press conference on Wednesday, saying, "To the two-thirds of voters who chose not to participate in the process yesterday, I hear you, too."

But the number of people who vote in midterm elections isn't the only problem according to Sanders. The Vermont independent also called typical levels of turnout in presidential elections "an international embarrassment." The number is higher in presidential years, but the U.S. still ranks behind 120 other countries in average turnout.

"We should not be satisfied with a 'democracy' in which more than 60 percent of our people don't vote and some 80 percent of young people and low-income Americans fail to vote," he added. "We can and must do better than that. While we must also focus on campaign finance reform and public funding of elections, establishing an Election Day holiday would be an important step forward."

Sanders said he would file the bill, titled ''Democracy Day Act of 2014," once Congress reconvenes next week.

- http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/11/07/bernie-sanders-election-day-holiday_n_6121674.html
fields.title: Sanders Wants to Make Election Day A Holiday

fields.name: Climate Change
fields.text:
What is climate change?

"Climate Change' encompasses global warming, which is the long-term warming of the planet, but also includes the broader range of changes that are happening to our planet. These include rising sea levels, shrinking mountain glaciers, accelerating ice melt in Greenland, Antarctica and the Arctic, and shifts in flower/plant blooming times. These are all consequences of the warming, which is caused mainly by the people burning fossil fuels and putting out heat-trapping gases into the air. Also to note, the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has increased the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide which are changing the natural gases.[1]

Is there evidence supporting climate change?

Throughout the last 650,000 years there have been seven cycles of glacial advance and retreat with the most recent ice age ending around 7,000 years ago near the time of human civilization. However, in regards to the current warming trends NASA says, "The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is very likely human-induced and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented in the past 1,300 years." We have been able to gather evidence through means of newer technology such as Earth-orbiting satellites. Sine evidence supporting this information that has been collected that directly points to climate change is sea level rise, global temperature rise, warming oceans, shrinking ice sheets, declining arctic ice sea, glacial retreat, and extreme events (hurricanes, increased rain fall, drought, etc...), ocean acidification, and decreased snow cover.[1] You can read more about the specific evidence and causes from climate change on NASA's website.

If the evidence is so Compelling, then how can people still deny its existence?

When we look at the 2016 presidential candidates we see a large amount of the candidates either

  1. Denying climate change is happening completely.
  2. Refusing to acknowledge it because the science is not compelling enough or refusing to acknowledge it for no reason.
  3. Kind of dodge around the issue not really answering the questions.
  4. Says that it exists but exploring new options to replace coal won't have a change or will cut all the jobs.
Some of the people who fall in these four categories are:
  • Ted Cruz[source]
  • Jeb Bush[source]
  • Carly Fiorina[source]
  • Mike Huckabee[source]
  • Bobby Jindal[source]
  • Rick Perryl[source]
  • Marco Rubio[source]
  • Rick Santorum[source]
  • Donald Trump[source]
  • Rick Santorum[source]
Why wouldn't any of these people acknowledge or move towards ways to actively fight climate change when 97% of the worldwide community of scientists agree that climate change is real, man-made, and an actual threat that we are way behind on preventing? Well, when you look at many of the donors for these people you will see a lot of oil companies who obviously do not want to see a reduction in oil production because that means a loss in money for them. For example, the Koch brothers plan to spend about $889 million budget for the 2016 elections only within the Republican Party[2]. To put that into perspective, during the 2012 presidential election between Mitt Romney and Barack Obama, they each spent just over a billion dollars between all of their funding for their campaign and everything. That means that one single group of brothers are going to spend almost as much on one candidate or across a couple candidates, what the entire Republican Party or the entire Democratic Party had spent on the entire 2012 elections.
Hillary Clinton is not exceptionally clean from this list either. While she talks a big game about fighting climate change and talking about the disaster that we face if we ignore it, she was known to promote fracking across the world while she was secretary of state, she takes a lot of money from oil companies (ExxonMobil, ConocoPhillips, etc...), she supported off-shore drilling, and she completely dodges questions in regards to the Keystone XL[3].

So what's so bad about the Koch Brothers wanting to invest in what they think is right?

Where does Bernie Sanders stand?

Stance in 2015

Stance in 2007




References
[1] Global Climate Change: Evidence. (2008, June 15). http://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/ [2] Koch brothers set $889 million budget for 2016. (2015, Jan 27). http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/01/26/koch-brothers-network-announces-889-million-budget-for-next-two-years/22363809/ [3] 8 things you need to know about Hillary Clinton and climate change. (2015, Apr 12). http://grist.org/climate-energy/8-things-you-need-to-know-about-hillary-clinton-and-climate-change/

fields.name: Education
fields.text:
Bernie's Stance on Higher Education

"... If somebody is bright and has the ability, not everybody does, and has the desire to get a higher education should we say to that person, 'No you can't do that because you don't have enough money or you are going to leave school $80,000 in debt?' or do we say, 'Hey we need your brains, we need your energy, to make us a competitive global economic nation.'"

Bernie Sanders thinks that higher education, specifically public colleges and universities should be a right to the American people and should be about whether you have the desire and intelligence to get a degree, not based solely on the fact of whether you can pay for it or not.

Ahh, That Just Means You Are Going To Tax Me More!

Not necessarily, to achieve this goal, it will cost about $70 billion. Bernie Sanders has already introduced legislation to make college and universities free by imposing a Wall Street speculation fee on investment houses, hedge funds, and other speculators of 0.5% on stock trades ($0.50 for every $100 worth of stock), a 0.1% fee on bonds, and a 0.005% fee on derivatives. It is estimated that this increase will bring in hundreds of billions a year which will be used to not only make college and university tuition free, but also create millions of jobs all across America[1].

What Else Is In This Legislation?

  • Work Study Reforms: "Today, the federal work study program receives less than $1 billion per year, and serves nearly 700,000 students. This legislation would expand the number of students and colleges that can offer part-time employment and participate in the federal work study program, and focus funding on schools that enroll high numbers of low-income students."
  • Restoration of Historically Low Student Loan Interest Rates: "The College for All Act would lower student loan interest rates by restoring the formula which was in effect until 2006. Student load interest rates would be cut almost in half for undergraduate students, dropping from 4.32% to just 2.32%."
  • Student Load Re-financing: "The College for All Act would enable borrowers to refinance their loans based on the interest rates available to current students."[1].

If This Was Such A Great Idea, Then Why Don't We See More Examples Of It?

This is one of the stances that Bernie Sanders has that makes him a Democratic Socialist, which has been a talking point when his name is brought up. But when actually asking Bernie Sanders about this subject, he does not deny that he is a Democratic Socialist, instead he asks what's wrong with that? He then usually points to countries with similar beliefs that he has (primarily the Scandinavian countries) and shows how they have very successful higher education programs which are nearly identical to the one he is trying to implement in the United States. All three of these countries, Denmark, Sweden, and Finland, all have a free higher education program in place, a healthcare as a right system (talked about in the Healthcare category), and all three have a higher standard of living and happiness then the United States. Somewhat attributed to education, childhood poverty is also a big issue that we face in our country. The three countries that have a free higher education system all are within 0%-10% in childhood poverty placing them in the top 7 countries in the world with lowest childhood poverty rates, while the United States has about a 25% childhood poverty rate placing us at 34th on the list being the 2nd to last developed country on the list of low childhood poverty rates[2].




References
[1] "Bernie Sanders Plans To Make College Free By Raising Taxes On Wall Street." PoliticusUSA. N.p., n.d. Web. 12 July 2015. [2] "Map: How 35 Countries Compare on Child Poverty (the U.S. Is Ranked 34th)." Washington Post. The Washington Post, 15 Apr. 2013. Web. 12 July 2015.

fields.name: Health Care
fields.text:
The state of Healthcare in the United States of America


Where does Bernie Sanders stand on Healthcare?

Bernie Sanders believes that the 2-tier system currently used in America is not the right direction for our healthcare system and instead thinks that healthcare, like education, is a right of all the people and he firmly believes in a single payer medicare for all system.

What about all of the criticisms of a single payer healthcare service (like wait times)?

fields.name: Honesty and Morality
fields.text:
Big Money in Politics

When it comes to modern politics, and especially with the ruling of citizens united (which was a supreme court case that allowed Super PACs the ability to receive money from corporations that is primarily used to create and promote hate ads toward other presidential candidates), we have a system in which honest politicians are an extremely hard to come by. Almost all politicians in this day and age are bought by big money, whether that is through big banks, wallstreet firms, or extremely wealthy corporations. This creates a system in which the people who are supposed to be representing America and what we stand for have a conflict of interest because their entire political careers are funded by people with almost polar opposite views than the American public.

Fortunately, we have very, very few political representatives left who do not adhere to the demands of big money interests and actually do their best to represent the people they were voted to represent. One of these people left standing is Bernie Sanders. Bernie Sanders has never received money from a Super PAC and is the only candidate this presidential election who can honestly say that they have no conflict of interest other than that of the majority of people in this country. This infograph is a good representation of the money and who supports who.


As you can see, Hillary Clinton recieves funding from corporations, banks, and media, while Bernie Sanders recieves funding from the people.


Negative Campaigning

Another thing about Bernie Sanders morality is that he absolutely hates negative campaigning. He has never, ever run a negative campaign ad in his life. If you are curious as the what these negative campaign ads are, here are a few (the first is a Romney attack ad from Obama's campaign and the second is a Obama attack ad from Romney's campaign):

Civil Rights

When it comes to civil rights and liberties, Bernie Sanders has always been the front runner pushing for a more equal society unlike some of his colleagues. As we are aware now by the many outcries, most in the Republican Party are trying to gather petitions for the Gay Marriage ruling, and do not believe that they should have equal rights. This viewpoint is pretty out of touch with most of America in regards to civil rights. Hillary Clinton has come out on this campaign and stated that she completely supports the right for Gay Marriage. That being said, here is a clip spanning her career on her stance to Gay Marriage along with the relevant polls from that same month/year.

This video is a prime example of the state of politics in America. Most politicians do not say the right thing, or do not say their specific opinion, but they are purely going to say what the majority of people want to hear which is bad. Fortunately, this would change with Bernie Sanders as president. Back in the early 1970s when Gay Marriage and Gay rights weren't a hot subject and not a majority either, Bernie Sanders wrote a letter while a candidate for the governor of Vermont that included...

Bernie Sanders and "... The Liberty Union believe that there are entirely too many laws that regulate human behavior. Let us abolish all laws which attempt to impose a particular brand of morality or 'right' on people. Let's abolish all laws dealing with abortion, drugs, sexual behavior (adultery, homosexuality, etc..)."

Mainstream Attention

If Bernie Sanders is such a perfect candidate, then why doesn't it seem that way on television? Well, one of the biggest factors here is who funds the television networks, they have complete control and are multi-billion dollar industries only interested in the best for their business. So what happens is, you have a presidential candidate breaking the status quo by saying that 1 in 4 corporations doesn't pay a nickle in tax and that needs to change which is not in the best interest for these companies. Here is a video describing Sanders' opinion on news outlets and mainstream media.

fields.name: Income Distribution
fields.text:
What is the current Income Distribution in America?

We live in a system right now, where the gap between the extremely wealthy and the middle class of America has never been as wide since the Great Depression. This is caused by many many different things one of the things that proves this is the stagnant middle class income. between the years of 2010-2013, the middle class median income stayed stuck at $96,500 while the poor median income actually dropped from $10,500 to $9,300. The wealth of upper-income families jumped an increasing amount from $595,300 to $639,400. This shows how clear it is that the gap between the wealthiest and the middle class and lower is increasing at an extremely large rate. The scariest part about this is that, as shown by the video, people perceive the system and gap to be not even close to what it actually is.[1]

How was this huge wealth gap caused?

How do we fix this problem?

This part is where a lot of the honesty and morality in our presidential candidates come into play. With all of our current presidential candidates, both Democrats and Republicans (excluding Bernie Sanders), receiving extraordinary amounts of money from big money interests, and then those candidates talk about how much they want to help grow the working class of America, can we really trust them? Most of these candidates are receiving money directly from the people who helped put us in the spot that they benefit from and the rest of America does not. Do you think they would be funding a campaign that would change their dominance over the country? Luckily, this for the 2016 campaign, Bernie Sanders has a lot of plans to try and fix this problem that we are facing in our nation and he has no reason not to mean what he's saying. After all, he has essentially had the same exact message since the early '70s when his career first began.

As discussed in this video, Bernie Sanders wants to start solving these problems of inequality by raising the minimum wage and create jobs to rebuild our crumbling infrastructure. Not discussed in this video is the stance he takes on wanting to stop loopholes that allow major corporations to stash their money in the Cayman Islands to prevent having to pay taxes on them. In regards to the first to plans, many will say, well those both cost a lot of money, raising the minimum wage will just make the price of goods go higher, the infrastructure is fine in our country, etc...

Whats wrong with the Infrastructure and what is Bernie's plan to fix it?

Raising the Minimum Wage



References
[1] Strachan, Maxwell. "U.S. Wealth Gap Hits Record High." The Huffington Post. TheHuffingtonPost.com, n.d. Web. 13 July 2015.
